title.justification: The title is found at the beginning of the paper and is consistently referred to throughout the text.
title.quote: Ramezanian-Panahi M, Abrevaya G, Gagnon-Audet J-C, Voleti V, Rish I and Dumas G (2022) Generative Models of Brain Dynamics. Front. Artif. Intell. 5:807406.

extractions.description: This review article provides an overview of different generative models used to analyze brain dynamics, discussing their applicability and limitations in computational neuroscience.

type.justification: The paper primarily discusses the theoretical aspects of generative models and their potential applications in neuroscience without presenting new empirical data.
type.quote: In the present review, we propose that a class of architectures known as generative models constitute an emergent set of tools with superior properties for reconstructing segregated and whole-brain dynamics.

name.justification: The paper focuses on computational models and methods used to understand and simulate brain dynamics, which falls under the field of computational neuroscience.
name.quote: The studies covered in this paper include fundamental models in computational neuroscience...

name.justification: The paper discusses machine learning methods and their application in generating models of brain dynamics.
name.quote: While the advances in ML literature enable new frontiers of generative models...

name.justification: The paper addresses nonlinear dynamics as a crucial aspect of modeling brain activity.
name.quote: We focus on generative models. Generative modeling can, in the current context, be distinguished from discriminative or classification modeling; in the sense that there is a probabilistic model of how observable data is generated by unobservable latent states.

name.justification: The paper refers to the Hodgkin-Huxley model as a benchmark in biophysical neuron modeling.
name.quote: The mechanism of this flow of ions was first explained by the influential Hodgkin-Huxley equations and corresponding circuits.

is_contributed.justification: The model is referenced as a fundamental example of biophysical neuron modeling, not as a new contribution in this paper.
is_contributed.quote: To address this, the authors suggest studying the population behavior instead of single-cell simulations. Despite all the limits, Izhikevich and Edelman (2008) is the first benchmark of whole-cortex modeling and the foundation of future detailed projects such as Blue Brain project (Markram, 2006) and MindScope (Koch et al., 2014).

is_executed.justification: The Hodgkin-Huxley model is discussed theoretically, not executed within the study.
is_executed.quote: The electrical current of the equivalent circuit is described by four differential equations that incorporate membrane capacity and the gating variables of the channels.

is_compared.justification: It is referred to as a standard against which other neuron models are discussed or developed.
is_compared.quote: The current state of thermodynamics accurately describes the macroscopic behavior of gas, so why not use this approximation to the many-body problems of neuronal populations? The analogous problem for a neural mass model can be described with the single-neuron activity and membrane potential as the microscopic parameter and the state of the neural ensemble in phase space as the macroscopic parameter.

referenced_paper_title.value: The movement of sodium and potassium ions during nervous activity, as illustrated by the Hodgkin-Huxley model.
referenced_paper_title.justification: The referenced paper provides foundational knowledge relevant to Hodgkin-Huxley models.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Hodgkin, A. L., and Huxley, A. F. (1952). A quantitative description of membrane current and its application to conduction and excitation in nerve. J. Physiol. 117, 500–544.

name.justification: The paper describes the Izhikevich model as an important simplification used in modeling large-scale neural dynamics.
name.quote: The spiking dynamics employed in this model comes from Izhikevich (2003) and it is a simplification of the Hodgkin-Huxley model as it outputs the firing rates instead of currents.

is_contributed.justification: The Izhikevich model is referenced rather than contributed in this research paper.
is_contributed.quote: Following Izhikevich and Edelman (2008), the Blue Brain Project...

is_executed.justification: The Izhikevich model is mentioned as a theoretical concept without details on execution within the study.
is_executed.quote: The significance of this simulation compared to preceding efforts is its inclusion of all cortical regions and some of their interplays in the form of cortico-cortical connections.

is_compared.justification: The model is discussed in relation to its contribution to whole-cortex modeling next to other approaches.
is_compared.quote: Despite all the limits, Izhikevich and Edelman (2008) is the first benchmark of whole-cortex modeling and the foundation of future detailed projects such as Blue Brain project (Markram, 2006) and MindScope (Koch et al., 2014).

referenced_paper_title.justification: The referenced paper by Izhikevich provides important details on the model's methodology and implications.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Izhikevich, E. M. (2003). Simple model of spiking neurons. IEEE Trans. Neural Netw. 14, 1569–1572.

name.justification: The Wilson-Cowan model is highlighted due to its influence in computational neuroscience.
name.quote: Seemingly the most influential model in computational neuroscience after Hodgkin-Huxley (Hodgkin and Huxley, 1952) is Wilson-Cowan (Wilson and Cowan, 1972) with presently over 3,000 mentions in the literature.

is_contributed.justification: The paper references the Wilson-Cowan model as a seminal work in the field rather than presenting it as a novel contribution.
is_contributed.quote: Wilson-Cowan model lays the foundation for many of the major theoretical advances.

is_executed.justification: The model is critically reviewed rather than executed directly within the research.
is_executed.quote: This model acknowledges the diversity of synapses by integrating distinct inhibitory and excitatory subpopulations.

is_compared.justification: It is compared to Hodgkin-Huxley and other neural population models in discussions of neural dynamics.
is_compared.quote: Seemingly the most influential model in computational neuroscience after Hodgkin-Huxley...

referenced_paper_title.value: Excitatory and inhibitory interactions in localized populations of model neurons.
referenced_paper_title.justification: The Wilson-Cowan model is extensively referenced and its pioneering work is detailed in the referenced paper.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Wilson, H. R., and Cowan, J. D. (1972). Excitatory and inhibitory interactions in localized populations of model neurons.

name.justification: The Kuramoto Model is used to describe synchronization in neural networks.
name.quote: Kuramoto model is frequently used for quantifying phase synchrony and for controlling unwanted phase transitions in neurological diseases like epileptic seizures and Parkinson’s.

is_contributed.justification: The model is not a contribution of this paper but is used as a reference point.
is_contributed.quote: Kuramoto model is widely used in physics for studying synchronization phenomena. It is relevant to neurobiological systems as it enables a phase reduction approach.

is_executed.justification: It is reviewed theoretically but not executed within this analysis.
is_executed.quote: Kuramoto can be extended to incorporate anatomical and effective connectivity and can expand from a low-level model of few-neuron activity to a stochastic population-level model with partial synchrony and rich dynamical properties.

is_compared.justification: The Kuramoto model is discussed in comparison with models like Wilson-Cowan for understanding neural oscillations.
is_compared.quote: There is significant literature on Kuramoto models on neural dynamics on different scales and levels. Strogatz (2000) is a conceptual review of decades of research on the principles of the general form of the Kuramoto model.

referenced_paper_title.justification: The Kuramoto model originates from research by Kuramoto on coupled oscillators, which is discussed in the referenced publication.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Kuramoto, Y. (1984). Chemical oscillations, waves, and turbulence. Springer Series in Synergetics, Vol. 19.

name.justification: The paper describes the Van der Pol oscillator as a model relevant for understanding neural dynamics.
name.quote: Another model relevant to neuroscience is the van der Pol (VDP) oscillator which is probably the simplest relaxation oscillator and a special case of the FitzHugh-Nagumo model.

is_contributed.justification: Van der Pol Oscillator is an established model discussed theoretically, not an invention of this paper.
is_contributed.quote: Van der Pol (VDP) oscillator which is probably the simplest relaxation oscillator (Guckenheimer and Holmes, 2013) and a special case of the FitzHugh-Nagumo model.

is_executed.justification: The paper doesn't indicate any execution of Van der Pol model.
is_executed.quote: VDP can also model neural populations.

is_compared.justification: The model is placed within a larger discussion of theoretical applications of dynamic models like Wilson-Cowan.
is_compared.quote: Van der Pol (VDP) oscillator which is probably the simplest relaxation oscillator (Guckenheimer and Holmes, 2013) and a special case of the FitzHugh-Nagumo model.

referenced_paper_title.justification: The Van der Pol oscillator is discussed in relation to fundamental research on nonlinear oscillations.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Guckenheimer, J., and Holmes, P. (2013). Nonlinear Oscillations, Dynamical Systems, and Bifurcations of Vector Fields. Springer Science & Business Media.

name.justification: The text references the Allen Brain Atlas as a dataset contributing genomic data valuable for analyzing neural dynamics.
name.quote: A notable effort in this regard is the Allen Brain Atlas (Jones et al., 2009) in which genomic data of mice, humans, and non-human primates... has been collected and mapped for understanding structural and functional architecture of the brain.

referenced_paper_title.value: An anatomically comprehensive atlas of the adult human brain transcriptome
referenced_paper_title.justification: The referenced paper provides the foundational work and details about the Allen Brain Atlas.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Jones, A. R., Overly, C. C., and Sunkin, S. M. (2009). The allen brain atlas: 5 years and beyond. Nat. Rev. Neurosci. 10, 821–828.

name.justification: The paper mentions the Human Connectome Project as an extensive source of data regarding brain connectivity.
name.quote: • Human Connectome Project: a large-scale structural and functional connectivity map of the human brain (coined as connectome in Sporns et al., 2005; Van Essen et al., 2013).

referenced_paper_title.value: The Wu-Minn Human Connectome Project: An overview
referenced_paper_title.justification: The referenced work outlines the project's objective and scale as described in the paper.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Van Essen, D. C., Smith, S. M., Barch, D. M., Behrens, T. E. J., Yacoub, E., and Ugurbil, K. (2013). The wu-minn human connectome project: an overview. Neuroimage 80, 62–79.

name.justification: The Blue Brain Project is frequently referenced as a large-scale synthesis attempt in brain modeling.
name.quote: Following Izhikevich and Edelman (2008), the Blue Brain Project (Markram, 2006) was founded in 2005 as a biological simulation of synapses and neurons of the neocortical microcircuitry.

referenced_paper_title.justification: The paper discusses the Blue Brain Project extensively, with respect to its contribution to understanding the brain.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Markram, H. (2006). The blue brain project. Nat. Rev. Neurosci. 7, 153–160.

name.justification: NEST is highlighted as a tool used in neural simulation for building ad-hoc models of spiking neurons.
name.quote: NEST is another popular package for building ad-hoc models of spiking neurons with adjusted parameters.

referenced_paper_title.justification: The paper identifies NEST as a reference tool for neural simulation, matching with Gewaltig and Diesmann's work.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Gewaltig, M.-O., and Diesmann, M. (2007). NEST (neural simulation tool). Scholarpedia 2, 1430.

name.justification: Brian is reviewed as a package for simulating neural dynamics, especially intended for single-compartment models.
name.quote: Brian (Stimberg et al., 2019) is a Python package for defining a customized spiking network.

referenced_paper_title.value: Brian 2, an intuitive and efficient neural simulator
referenced_paper_title.justification: This paper version provides details into the functionalities and capabilities of Brian as referenced in the text.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Stimberg, M., Brette, R., and Goodman, D. F. (2019). Brian 2, an intuitive and efficient neural simulator. Elife 8, e47314.
